page.title: 05HEDGEROWS AND VERGES.
page.content: The hedgerows of this area are mainly hawthorn, elder and hazel, interspersed with dog-roses intertwined with brambles. At the end of June the hedgerows were alive with thrushes, chaffinches, wrens and blackbirds whose nests, in the dense undergrowth, were empty, the fledgelings having flown. The more unusual yellowhammers and long-tailed tits could also be seen. Beneath the hedges there is evidence of mice and voles, stoats and rabbits, while in one place an old, disused badgers' sett may be seen. The roadside verges are profuse with wild plants, the main ones being mullein, chervil, garlic mustard and vetches. Various types of grass include onion couch, couch, bent, brome and meadow-grasses.
